Haptic discrimination of virtual surface slope
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 28 August 2013

Haptic discrimination of virtual surface slope

  • Inwook Hwang1,
  • Sunghoon Yim1 &
  • Seungmoon Choi1 

Virtual Reality volume 17, pages205–218(2013)Cite this article

  • 299 Accesses

  • Metrics details

Abstract

We report the difference thresholds of the slope of a virtual surface rendered via a force–feedback haptic interface with the body frontal plane as a reference. The factors varied in experiments were the stiffness of a virtual plane, the lateral velocity with which the haptic probe scanned the plane, the length of a scanning interval, the movement direction of the probe to the body frontal plane (toward or away from the body), and lateral scanning direction (left-to-right or right-to-left). Measured slope thresholds ranged from 8.33° to 12.74° and were generally higher than or similar to previously published thresholds for haptic orientation or angle discrimination. The results suggested that haptic slope discriminability was independent of surface stiffness and lateral scanning velocity. Slope discrimination was largely affected by the lateral scan distance, indicating that the terminal difference of probe normal position can be an important sensory cue. In terms of scan direction, inward or rightward scans resulted in better slope discrimination than outward or leftward scans, respectively. These thresholds and findings have implications for haptics applications that involve geometric model modification or simplification of virtual objects while preserving their perceptual properties.

Introduction

In computer haptics, methods to represent the shape of a 3D object are of fundamental significance, since they affect all aspects of performance including processing speed and perceptual fidelity. Many approaches exist for object shape modeling, such as 3D polygonal mesh, NURBS, and implicit functions. Most of them have been adapted from more advanced computer graphics. At present, the 3D mesh is the most prevalent model owing to its great modeling power, seamless integration with visual rendering, and excellent hardware acceleration using GPU. The most critical parameter for mesh models is spatial resolution, that is, the number of polygons used to represent object geometry. However, relatively little is known about the relationship between modeling resolution and haptic perceptual information, even though such knowledge is a prerequisite for appropriate mesh manipulation. Recent examples involving mesh manipulation include haptic level-of-detail (Payandeh et al. 2005), haptic data compression (Hinterseer and Steinbach 2006; Kuschel et al. 2006; Zadeh et al. 2008), haptic data watermarking (Prattichizzo et al. 2007), and multiple-attribute scientific data haptization (Cheon et al. 2008) (see Sect. 2.1 for further details).

In this article, we report an experimental study pertaining to the human discriminability of the slope (or orientation) of a haptic surface. Consider a process in which a haptic probe explores a virtual object surface represented by a 3D mesh. Each scan on the object surface consists of a number of short scans on the polygons lying along the scanning path. To perceive the object shape, the user needs to temporally integrate the information of individual polygons and edges. Therefore, understanding our capability of perceiving the slope of a polygon, or a plane encompassing the polygon, is essential for building quantitative knowledge on how mesh manipulation affects the perception of object shape.

As reviewed in Sect. 2.2, there has been a body of research pertaining to perception of angle, orientation, and curvature, emphasizing on the theoretical aspects. Although valuable, how to transform this knowledge to the forms adequate for 3D haptic mesh manipulation is not straightforward because of the differences between experimental setups and environments for virtual haptic exploration [albeit see a study by Giachritsis et al. (2009)]. In addition, the factors that must be determined often independently of object geometry for haptic rendering, but not necessarily for real object perception, e.g., surface stiffness, have not been investigated. As such, the present study aims at providing a large set of difference thresholds of virtual surface slope perception that can be directly used for haptic mesh manipulation and investigating the effects of the factors that are generally accepted as important for haptic rendering or shape perception.

Specifically, we measured the difference thresholds of a virtual plane slope rendered by a desktop force–feedback haptic interface. As depicted in Fig. 1, the reference stimulus was the body coronal (frontal) plane, and the comparison stimulus was a vertical plane slanted with a certain slope. Experimental factors were the stiffness of a virtual plane (material factor), the lateral velocity at which the haptic probe scans a plane (exploratory), the length of a scanning interval (geometric and exploratory), the movement direction of the probe perpendicular to the scan direction (exploratory; outward or inward), and lateral scanning direction (exploratory; leftward or rightward). As a result, we obtained 18 difference thresholds for slope discrimination measured under various experimental conditions. From these thresholds, the effects of the five factors on the slope discriminability were examined and compared with the available knowledge in haptic perception, which led to a few new findings. The comparisons were accompanied by analysis of the associated exploratory parameters, such as scanning movement patterns and applied force, also in order to identify the sensory cues responsible for slope perception.

In the rest of this paper, we summarize related work on haptic mesh manipulation and human shape perception in Sect. 2. Methods for the experiments are presented in Sect. 3, and experimental results and discussions are in Sect. 4. A general discussion is given in Sect. 5, followed by conclusions in Sect. 6.

Related work

In this section, we introduce the prior computer haptics research involving mesh manipulation that motivated the present study. We then provide a literature review on human shape perception.

Mesh manipulation in computer haptics

There exist vast databases of mesh models constructed for graphics and visualization. Those obtained by laser range scanners, vision systems, and medical imaging devices contain the fine details of object surfaces. These models can be extremely complex, comprising billions of triangles (Garland 1999). Rendering such models in real time for haptic interaction is often infeasible. This situation is greatly exacerbated for dynamic or deformable objects or when interaction is modeled between two rigid objects for six degrees of freedom (DOF) rendering (Lin and Otaduy 2008). In comparison with a large amount of model simplification techniques present in graphics (Garland 1999), such efforts have been scarce in haptics.

Recently, the need for model manipulation algorithms has emerged in computer haptics. For example, Payandeh et al. (2005) confirmed the feasibility of haptic level-of-detail (LOD) for deformable object rendering. In computer graphics, LOD techniques transform complex object models, i.e., of a large number of polygons to simpler models, i.e., of a smaller number of polygons appropriate for a given condition (e.g., long distance view). It was demonstrated that low-resolution and high-resolution models of the same object can be perceptually very similar or identical, as a first step for haptic LOD research. Another active area is haptic data compression, which aims to reduce the object model size for telepresence while maintaining stability and transparency. Hinterseer and Steinbach (2006) proposed a simple lossy compression technique for 3D haptic data using the dead zone of a point that includes neighbors indistinguishable from that point by touch. Kuschel et al. (2006) empirically compared several lossy data compression algorithms for haptic telepresence using performance indexes such as compression ratio, passivity, and transparency. The detection thresholds of force changes perceived during virtual surface scanning were also published for data compression (Zadeh et al. 2008).

Whereas these studies are concerned with model simplification, some applications require model modification while preserving the model resolution. Haptic digital watermarking is one of such examples. It adds imperceptible haptic watermarks to an object model, for the copyright protection of haptic contents, by perturbing the positions and orientations of polygonal primitives or superimposing micro-textures on the polygons (Prattichizzo et al. 2007). Another study is related to the haptization (haptic visualization) of nanoscale scientific data, wherein the topography of a haptic surface is rendered with continuously varying stiffness information (Cheon et al. 2008). It was reported that the conventional penalty-based algorithms can lead to a distorted perception of surface topography, due to a human exploratory behavior named force constancy—the user tends to maintain constant contact force during object surface scanning for shape perception (Choi et al. 2005). One effective way to resolve the problem was to adjust the surface height adaptively based on the stiffness variation and the discriminability of surface slope change.

Knowledge of the human discriminability of virtual plane slopes can be instrumental in designing effective algorithms for all of the above applications. In Cheon et al. (2008), we reported the difference thresholds of a surface slope measured under limited experimental conditions. Rendered force directions were always constant and normal to the body frontal plane shown in Fig. 1. In the present study, we have significantly expanded the experimental conditions by taking into account the effects of various factors. Force direction is now normal to rendered planes, as is common in 3D mesh rendering.

Haptic shape perception

Most research on haptic perception of object geometry has used angle or curvature as a representative measure. For instance, Voisin et al. (2002a, b) examined the two-dimensional angle discriminability of cutaneous input from the index finger and that of proprioceptive input from the shoulder or wrist. The addition of the cutaneous input was shown to improve the discriminability. Louw et al. (2000, 2002) showed that difference thresholds for a Gaussian shape monotonically decrease with its maximum spatial gradient. In addition, van der Horst and Kappers (2007) compared the difference thresholds of curvature when samples were explored with the same finger or two different fingers. The two-finger condition was generally worse at curvature discrimination.

Studies concerned with distortions in haptic spatial perception are also relevant. For example, Fasse et al. (2000) measured orientation detection thresholds using a robot manipulator grasped in a power grip. Participants answered whether virtual lines were oriented left or right of the straight-ahead direction. The subjective orientations were biased by 5° and 4.5° for the sagittal and frontal planes, respectively. Henriques and Soechting (2003) examined the bias and sensitivity in haptic perception of several geometric features using a similar setup. In particular, the absolute bias that exists in the orientation perception of a tilted surface was shown to increase with the distance between shoulder and hand. Besides, Kappers and Koenderink (1999) investigated haptic parallelity perception. A reference bar was presented at four different orientations, and blindfolded participants were asked to rotate a test bar such that it felt parallel to the reference bar. It was observed that what was perceived as haptically parallel deviated significantly from what was physically parallel, which could be as much as 40°.

In general, a computer haptics application requires psychophysical data obtained in an environment that is identical or very similar to that of the application. To our knowledge, most of the related studies in haptic perception focused on theoretical aspects and did not offer the experimental data that can be directly used for haptic geometry model manipulation, in part because of the differences in object geometry representation. Our treatment in this paper assumes 3D polygonal mesh models, being more oriented to computer haptics applications.

After all experiments of this study were completed, we found that Giachritsis et al. (2009) had recently investigated perception of surface orientation emphasizing on the role of spatial integration of the kinesthetic and proprioceptive stimuli. In this study, participants scanned virtual slanted surfaces back and forth with a PHANToM 1.5 haptic device with a thimble interface (so one-finger scan) in different lengths (35, 70, 140, and 245 mm). The scan direction was the straight-ahead direction (negative z-direction in Fig. 1). Results showed that the reproduction errors and discrimination thresholds of orientation perception improved with scan length. This suggests that sequentially increasing spatial integration can make proprioception from the shoulder–elbow system more reliable. As this study bears an appreciable resemblance to the present study in experimental design, we compare the two studies whenever appropriate in the rest of this paper.

Methods

The methods used to estimate the difference thresholds of virtual surface slope are described in this section. The investigation consisted of four experiments, and each experiment assessed the effect of one or two independent factors.

Participants

We recruited 48 participants, and they were evenly assigned to the four experiments (12 each). Their demographic information is summarized in Table 1. All the participants except four were inexperienced users of a force–feedback device. They did not report any sensorimotor impairments that could have compromised experimental results. Each participant was paid at a rate of 10,000 KRW (approximately 9 USD) per hour for compensation.

Apparatus

As shown in Fig. 2, haptic virtual planes were rendered using a PHANToM (Sensable; model 1.0A) with the stylus interface. This model can provide 3-DOF force feedback and is one of the most popular devices for haptics research. A 17-inch monitor displayed visual scenes. A participant sat comfortably in front of the monitor while holding the stylus with the right hand. The participant entered responses with the left hand using a keyboard. A vertical plate was placed between the monitor and the PHANToM to prevent visual exposure of stylus movements.

We asked the two left-handed participants in Exp. 4 to use their right hand for surface scanning so as not to have hand as an independent factor. They reported no problem in handling the PHANToM stylus with their right hand. In general, the angular sensitivity of the shoulder and elbow is similar between the left and right arms (van Beers et al. 1998). We also confirmed that their results were not noticeably different from those of the right-handed participants.

Stimuli

As shown in Fig. 2, the haptic planes were placed 25–35 cm in front of and 30–40 cm to the right of the body, as common for a desktop haptic device with a visual display. The planes are further depicted in Fig. 3. Let the PHANToM stylus position at time t be

$$ {\bf p}(t) = ( p_{x}(t) , p_{y}(t) , p_{z}(t)). $$
(1)

The haptic plane was specified in the Hessian normal form such that

$$ {\bf n} = \left( n_{x} , n_{y} , n_{z} \right) = \left( \sin \theta , 0 , \cos \theta \right), $$
(2)
$$ {\bf n} \cdot {\bf x} = - 0.5 L \sin \theta, $$
(3)

where θ is the plane slope angle, n is the plane normal, x = (x , y , z ) is a point on the plane, and L is the length of a scanning path on the x-axis. The absolute value of the right hand term in (3) is the distance between the origin (located at the center of scanning paths on the frontal plane) and the hapti plane.

To render the haptic plane, we used the following proxy model:

$$ {\bf h}(t) = {\bf p}(t) - \left( {\bf n} \cdot {\bf p}(t) + 0.5 L \sin \theta \right) {\bf n}. $$
(4)

This proxy represents the closest point between p(t) and the haptic plane and can be easily derived (Weisstein 2010). A force component for plane rendering was computed using a penalty-based rule, such that

$$ {\bf F}^1(t)= \left( F^1_x(t), F^1_y(t), F^1_z(t) \right) $$
(5)
$$ = \left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {K({\mathbf{h}}(t) - {\mathbf{p}}(t))} \hfill & {{\text{if}}\,({\mathbf{h}}(t) - {\mathbf{p}}(t))\cdot{\mathbf{n}} > 0} \hfill \\ {\mathbf{0}} \hfill & {{\text{otherwise}}} \hfill \\ \end{array} } \right. $$
(6)

where K is the virtual plane stiffness. Note that F 1 y (t) was always zero (no vertical forces) and that θ = 0 rendered the zero-slope vertical plane (parallel to the frontal plane).

During scans, the stylus was actively controlled to stay on the xz-plane using a force field in order to minimize its up-down movements along the height (y) direction. This was necessary because such up-down movements increase the scan length for the same normal displacement of the stylus in the depth (z) direction. The force field was

$$ {\bf F}^2(t) = \left( 0, K^* \left( p_y (\hat{t}) - p_y (t) \right), 0 \right), $$
(7)

where \(\hat{t}\) is the scan onset time. K * was fixed to 0.4 N/mm. Then, the final force command was

$$ {\bf F}(t) = {\bf F}^1(t) + {\bf F}^2(t). $$
(8)

The visual scene displayed on the monitor is shown in Fig. 4. In addition to an interval number, the scene displayed four regions painted in different colors to aid scan movements (see Sect. 3.5 for their roles). Only solid colors were used since visual textures can affect slant discrimination (Knill 1998). The PHANToM stylus position was represented by a cone. The visual planes were always flat and did not reveal any visual depth cue for slope perception. For the same reason, the stylus cone remained on the visual planes and only indicated the (x, y) position of the stylus.

Experimental conditions

For experiment design, we considered the five factors that are important for haptic rendering or were suspected to affect the haptic discriminability of a slanted plane according to the previous preliminary investigation (Cheon et al. 2008). They were the stiffness of a virtual plane (K), the lateral velocity with which the haptic probe scans the plane (V), the length of a scan interval (L), the direction of probe movement normal to the reference plane (N; outward from or inward to the body), and the direction of probe movement tangential to the reference plane (T; rightward or leftward). Their effects were examined in four experiments, as summarized in Fig. 5 and Table 2.

The experimental condition commonly included in all experiments was K = 0.35 N/mm, V = 40 mm/s, L = 50 mm, and NT = OR. Exps. 1, 2, and 3 had one independent factor, while Exp. 4 had two. In Exp. 1, plane stiffness was the variable of interest, and four values (0.20, 0.35, 0.50, and 0.65 N/mm) were tested. Stiffness less than 0.20 N/mm was not considered since such low-stiffness surfaces feel too mushy to define a boundary. The highest stiffness level, 0.65 N/mm, was chosen to guarantee stable rendering with the PHANToM (Choi and Tan 2004). In Exp. 2, the target of investigation was scan velocity, and four values (20, 30, 40, and 50 mm/s) were used. In Exp. 3, scan interval length was an independent factor, covering 20–70 mm in a 10-mm step. In Exp. 4, the effects of normal and tangential movement directions were examined in a 2 × 2 factorial design. See the text in Fig. 5 and Table 2 for their configurations. In each experiment, the order of experimental conditions was balanced using a Latin square to minimize the order effect.

The above conditions are determined taking the current status of haptic interfaces and modeling methods into account. Real stiff objects have greatly higher stiffness by several orders of magnitude than the maximum stiffness used in our experiment, but rendering such high stiffness is infeasible with current haptic interfaces. In addition, desktop haptic interfaces have a relative small workspace, and the workspace that provides precise position sensing and force control resolution is even smaller. For example, the workspace recommended for use by the manufacturer is 17 × 14.5 × 8 cm for the PHANToM model used in the experiment. Further, general mesh objects consist of a great number of small polygons, and the largest scan interval (7 cm) used in our experiment is by far longer than such polygons. Therefore, the emphasis of our experimental conditions was on looking into the parameter ranges relevant to the current haptic rendering with relatively fine resolution.

Procedures

Under each experimental condition, a difference threshold was measured using the three-alternative, forced choice, one-up three-down adaptive staircase method (Levitt 1971). Each trial consisted of three alternatives (or time intervals). Two of the three intervals presented a virtual plane with zero slope (the reference stimulus), and the other one a slanted plane with a certain slope (the comparison stimulus), in a randomized manner. In this design, the probability of a correct response is 1/3. Compared with two-alternative designs, three-alternative methods lead to less threshold variability and converge faster when used together with adaptive staircase procedures (Shelton and Scarrow 1984). This method has been frequently used for haptic threshold measurements [e.g., Brisben et al. (1999); Morioka and Griffin (2005)].

On the onset of each interval, the participant moved the PHANToM stylus onto a start region, rectangle A shown in Fig. 4, on the left side. After the stylus touched rectangle A, rectangle B started moving from left to right at a predetermined velocity. This provided the participant with a reference for scanning velocity. The participant was instructed to follow the moving rectangle B while maintaining contact with the plane, until arriving at a finish zone (rectangle C in Fig. 4) on the right side. If the stylus fell outside the moving rectangle during scanning or lost contact with the haptic plane, the interval was repeated. After the third interval, the participant answered in which interval a plane felt sloped by pressing a corresponding numeric key. In experimental conditions requiring right-to-left scans (2 of 18; see Table 2), the locations of start and finish zones were switched.

We confirmed the effectiveness of this velocity control strategy in pilot experiments. In fact, each participant made only few errors in the main sessions (about 4 % of strokes). In addition, the velocity control made the participants attend to the monitor screen, similarly to the typical haptic exploration of virtual objects.

During the trials, three consecutive correct responses led to a decrement of stimulus intensity, and one incorrect response to an increment, both by a predefined step size. The threshold estimated by this one-up three-down procedure corresponds to the 79.4 percentile point on a psychometric function (Levitt 1971). The initial slope was set to be much higher than the expected threshold level found in pilot experiments. The step size \(\Updelta \theta\) was expressed in dB, where positive \(\Updelta \theta\) increased the slope and vice versa. Footnote 1 \(|\Updelta \theta|\) was initially 4 dB (for faster convergence) and then reduced to 1 dB (for finer resolution) after the first three response reversals (a reversal occurred if the slope value changed from increasing to decreasing, or vice versa). A series of trials was terminated after 12 reversals at the 1-dB step size. An example trace of stimulus intensity changes is given in Fig. 6.

During the experiment, the participants were instructed to attend to the display screen and hold the stylus perpendicular to the frontal plane. The latter was to minimize orientation changes between head and arm, which can otherwise affect perception of the elbow joint angle (Knox and Hodges 2005). The experimenter watched the participant throughout the experiment and gave verbal comments on any incorrect pose.

Prior to the main sessions, the participants went through training sessions, especially to become familiar with the scanning procedure including velocity control, under several selected conditions. It took 5–15 min to finish one experimental condition. A break of 5–10 min was enforced between experimental conditions. Each of Exps. 1, 2, and 3 took about 120 min for completion, and Exp. 4 took about 180 min.

Data analysis

In each experimental condition, the slope values where the last 12 reversals (6 peaks and 6 valleys) at the 1-dB step size occurred (e.g., the rightmost 12 reversal points in Fig. 6) were recorded and averaged pairwise, resulting in six estimates of a difference threshold. All subsequent analyses including statistical tests were performed on the logarithms of the thresholds. Thus, a final threshold corresponded to the geometric mean of the six estimates.

During the experiment, we also recorded stylus trajectories and force commands in all trials. Note that the contact force applied by the participant was not measured directly, e.g., via a force sensor. Instead, it was estimated as force command F 1(t) in (6). This leads to good estimation if a stylus trajectory is smooth without abrupt accelerations, indicating equilibriums between participant-applied and device-generated forces. This force balance usually holds during haptic surface scan (Choi et al. 2005).

Results and discussion

The mean difference thresholds of plane slope ranged from 8.33 to 12.74° and are presented in Fig. 7 for all the four experiments. Based on these results, the rest of this section discusses the effects of the five independent factors on surface slope orientation sensitivity. To identify contributing sensory cues, we also examine the measured physical stimuli—the probe trajectory (position, spatial gradient, and temporal gradient) and the interaction force between the haptic interface and the participant’s hand, as in Fasse et al. (2000).

Exp. 1: Effect of surface stiffness

Figure 7a suggests that plane stiffness K was not a statistically significant factor for slope discrimination. This was confirmed by a one-way repeated-measures ANOVA [F(3, 33) = 0.95, p = 0.427]. To find its reasons, we examined the position trajectories of the PHANToM stylus measured in Exp. 1.

An example of typical stylus paths is given in Fig. 8, where penetration depth (distance between the probe and the reference plane) is plotted against lateral scan position p x (t). The solid line represents a scan path of one participant in a trial for θ = 11.9° (or closest to it), measured when K = 0.20 N/mm. Scan paths for other stiffness values were selected in the same manner from the record of the same participant. From Fig. 8, it is evident that the four lines seem parallel and keep their penetration depths almost constant after some initial fluctuations. In addition, average penetration depth decreased with increasing surface stiffness. These two behaviors are in close agreement with the force constancy theory (Choi et al. 2005); if the user maintains constant contact force during a scan, the probe path remains parallel to the scanned surface and its penetration depth is proportional to the user-applied force and the inverse of surface stiffness.

To look further into this issue, we paid attention to how much contact forces varied during each scan. For this purpose, the mean m F and the standard deviation σ F of contact forces were computed from each scan data. Their ratio \(\tilde{\sigma}_F = \sigma_F /m_F\) indicates the spread of contact forces within a scan normalized by the mean m F . Note that m F generally depends on the participant and the experimental condition. The subjective means of \(\tilde{\sigma}_F\) ranged from 0.158 to 0.286 and the within-subjects standard deviations ranged from 0.035 to 0.108, which are quite small. Note that these small values include the influence of the initial force fluctuations that occur while the incoming momentum of the hand-stylus system is canceled out (e.g., scan positions between 0 and 20 mm in Fig. 8). Decreasing contact forces observed during contact release were also accounted for (e.g., scan positions between 45 and 50 mm in Fig. 8). We further excluded these contact forces from analysis by removing the data of the first 20-mm and last 5-mm scan intervals. Then, ranges of the subjective means and standard deviations of \(\tilde{\sigma}_F\) were even reduced to 0.044–0.142 and 0.024–0.084.

Therefore, although Exp. 1 was not designed to examine the force constancy theory, this additional analysis indeed supports that the participants tended to apply an invariant force level during scanning. This appears to be a reason behind the result that surface stiffness hardly contributed to the discrimination of virtual surface slope in Exp. 1.

Exp. 2: Effect of scan velocity

The difference thresholds measured in Exp. 2 are shown in Fig. 7b. The lateral velocity of scanning a plane V had no significant effect on the difference thresholds [one-way repeated-measures ANOVA; F(3, 33) = 1.44, p = 0.248].

For surface slope angle θ, the temporal derivative of the stylus position normal to the reference plane, i.e., normal movement velocity, can be estimated as \(V \tan\theta\) if a stylus path remains parallel to a haptic plane as in Fig. 8. Hence, the result of Exp. 2 suggests that the temporal derivative is irrelevant to slope perception sensitivity, at least for the range of tested scan velocities (20–50 mm/s). A similar tendency was also reported by Voisin et al. (2002a) where participants’ performance for 2D angle perception was independent of scan speed varied in 87–372 mm/s. This can be regarded as an example where efferent information on the motor intent (velocity in the scan direction) properly compensates for afferent information on the dynamic stimulus for perception of spatial features (velocity in the normal direction) (Fasse et al. 2000).

Exp. 3: Effect of scan interval length

As shown in Fig. 7c, the scan interval length L appears to have a strong influence on the difference thresholds. The thresholds decrease with L and then saturate for L ≥ 40 mm. A one-way repeated-measures ANOVA confirmed the statistical significance of L [F(5, 55) = 24.14, p < 0.001]. In addition, a Tukey’s HSD test identified four statistically different groups: L = 20, 30, {40, 60, 70} and {40, 50, 70} mm. These findings indicate that the slope discriminability improved for short scan distances, but it began to plateau for scan distances longer than 40 mm.

The above result is in line with those of Exp. 3 in Giachritsis et al. (2009). The two experiments had similar designs. Notable differences between our study and Giachritsis et al.’s were PHANToM model: 1.0 versus 1.5 (a larger model), interface type: stylus (three-finger grasp) versus thimble (one finger), orientation of the haptic plane: frontal versus horizontal–frontal, scan direction: left–right versus front–back, the number of scans allowed: once versus several times within a time limit, scan velocity control: yes versus no, the number of response alternatives: 3 AFC versus 2 AFC, and the type of adaptive staircase: single versus double (interwoven). In Giachritsis et al. (2009), difference thresholds decreased from 14° to 8° with the scan length from 35 to 245 mm, but those for the scan lengths larger than 70 mm tended to saturate and formed the same statistical group. The difference thresholds of our study showed similar results; those for the scan lengths between 40 ≤ L ≤ 70 mm were near 8° without statistically significant difference. The faster saturation in our study might have resulted from the differences in the experimental conditions.

Given a slanted surface, what increases with scan length is the probe movement distance perpendicular to scan direction. Hence, this normal displacement can be a reliable sensory cue for surface slope discrimination. For confirmation, we computed the normal probe displacement \(\Updelta p_{z}^{*}\) that would occur for the threshold angle θ * shown in Fig. 7c by \(\Updelta p_z^* = L \tan \theta^*\). Results are shown in Fig. 9. \(\Updelta p_z^*\) increased from 4.5 to 11.1 mm with L. These values allow reliable perception; for instance, the position displacements converted from curvature discrimination thresholds without force direction cues were 2.5–3.5 mm (Drewing and Ernst 2006). However, why \(\Updelta p_z^*\) increased with L, instead of being a constant, remains a question. It might be because gravitational torque acting on the joints in the wrist–shoulder system can increase noise in proprioception for longer scans (Giachritsis et al. 2009).

It is also possible that the final hand position in the z-direction at the end of a scan could be an additional sensory cue for slope discrimination because of the same positions of the reference haptic plane were used in all scans. Although the participant tend to maintain a constant contact force within a scan, the contact force usually varies between scans. In our experiments, the penetration depth along the z-axis could vary between scans to a maximum of about 8 mm. This range was quite large compared to the normal displacement (4.5–11.1 mm) of the planes at the threshold level shown in Fig. 9. Hence, while absolute arm position can be an effective cue for large slopes, its contribution to threshold estimation seems to be much less significant.

After the experiment, some participants reported that they also relied on the changes of force direction for slope discrimination. Note that response force direction was orthogonal to each haptic plane, thus independent of scan interval length. However, a longer scan interval can allow us to perceive the force direction over an extended length, and this spatial integration of proprioceptive information may improve the sensitivity of force direction perception (Giachritsis et al. 2009). In the haptic perception literature, discrimination thresholds of force direction are scarce, except those reported in Barbagli et al. (2006) for the passive case where force was applied by a haptic interface to the fingertip resting in space. This threshold was about 28°, which is much larger than the thresholds of this study. Nonetheless, active exploration with prolonged, continuous exposure to a force field is likely to enhance the directional sensitivity. Therefore, from the current data, we are unable to draw clear conclusions regarding the contribution of force direction cues to surface slope discrimination. Further clarification would require a comparison between two cases of force direction: normal to the surface (this study) versus normal to the frontal plane (along the z-axis in Fig. 3), where the latter case renders constant-direction response forces regardless of surface slope.

Exp. 4: Effects of normal and tangential probe movement directions

In Exp. 4, the difference thresholds were 9.77, 10.36, 9.25, and 9.86° for the four conditions shown in Fig. 7d. A two-way repeated-measures ANOVA showed that the normal and tangential movement directions of the probe, N and T, were statistically significant or marginally significant for the difference thresholds [F(1, 11) = 8.61, p = 0.014 for N and F(1, 11) = 4.44, p = 0.059 for T]. However, their interaction, which represents slope direction (clockwise or counterclockwise from the frontal plane in the top view; see Table 2; Fig. 5), was not significant [F(1, 11) < 0.01, p = 0.989].

The above results indicate that the inward planes (IL and IR) were easier to discriminate than the outward planes (OL and OR). In fact, most participants commented that the force rendered by the PHANToM often felt increased during inward plane scans. We could indeed confirm the reported behavior in the measured response force trajectories. Fig. 10 shows the average response forces of the four experimental conditions plotted for scan position. The response forces of the inward planes in Fig. 10 were apt to increase almost until the end of scans, but such patterns did not appear for the outward planes. While scanning on an inward plane toward the body center, the arm needs to be contracted so that its movement follows the plane. However, insufficient arm contraction is likely to occur when no visual information on the plane slope is available, especially for desktop haptic interfaces that have limited output force. This can increase the penetration depth of the probe and also the rendering force.

The left-to-right scans (IR and OR) led to marginally smaller difference thresholds than the right-to-left scans (IL and OL). There exists evidence that the sensitivity of the elbow–shoulder system depends on the hand position and is degraded when the arm is extended (Kappers and Koenderink 1999; Haggard et al. 2000). In our experimental conditions, both rightward and leftward scans traversed the same path, but their start and end positions were reversed. The fact that the left-to-right scans, which started in more sensitive hand-arm configurations, resulted in smaller thresholds may imply that the participants used nonuniform perceptual weights for spatial information integration, i.e., a higher weight on the initial perceptual information but decreasing weights as the scan proceeded. Since most previous studies allowed repeated bidirectional scans, such asymmetric behaviors have not been reported. Underlying reasons for this finding are largely unknown and can be a subject of future research.

General discussion

In this section, we discuss the experimental results in view of more general contexts.

Implications to geometric model processing

The difference thresholds presented in this paper can be referred to as a guideline for 3D mesh processing in haptics applications. Three-dimensional mesh simplification, which has long been studied and is quite sophisticated at the moment in computer graphics (Garland 1999), can be a good example. Mesh simplification techniques use a series of primitive operations. For instance, edge collapse removes an edge between two vertices and unites the two polygons separated by the edge to one polygon. Guaranteeing perceptually equivalent local geometry before and after an edge collapse is a necessary condition for perception-preserving mesh simplification. To do the same for haptic rendering, we need to determine whether we can differentiate between the orientations of two polygons before an edge collapse and that of the united polygon after the edge collapse as well as whether the angle between the two polygons feels different from a flat plane after the edge collapse, both by touch. The difference thresholds of slope perception measured in this paper can be crucial information for the former criterion. For the latter, angle difference thresholds, e.g., those in Voisin et al. (2002a), can be taken into account, although data measured under the use of a force–feedback device can be more relevant. Similarly, the difference thresholds of plane orientation and angle can be taken into account to judge perceptual equivalence after other primitive operations such as vertex removal.

Another primary application area is mesh modification without reducing the number of polygons. In this case, research issues can be formulated as how to alter the positions and orientations of polygons while achieving application goals and preserving perceptual information, e.g., how to add imperceptible copyright information into a 3D mesh for haptic watermarking (Prattichizzo et al. 2007) or how to unnoticeably remove accumulated local geometry changes for scientific data haptization (Cheon et al. 2008). The difference thresholds of plane orientations and angle can also be directly used for these applications.

The effects of the five factors on slope discriminability also have important implications to mesh modification. (1) Stiffness: In most cases, geometry and stiffness models of an object are separate in virtual object rendering. The result that human slope discriminability is not affected by virtual object stiffness allows mesh models to be manipulated without considering rendering stiffness, which greatly facilitates the process. (2) Scan velocity: Exploratory factors such as scan velocity are determined by the user and are only available in run time. The fact that scan velocity is not relevant to slope discrimination is an important advantage, suggesting that both off-line (e.g., mesh simplification) or online mesh manipulation (e.g., data compression) do not need to take scan velocity into account. (3) Scan length: The dependence of human orientation sensitivity to scan length shown in Exp. 3 has crucial bearing on haptic geometry manipulation. For example, this means that for optimality, the degree of model simplification must be consistent with the physical size of the model to be rendered by a haptic device, which is often unknown in off-line preprocessing. Therefore, haptic LOD schemes using multiple-resolution meshes may be mandatory for the best performance. (4) Scan direction: The discrimination thresholds dependent on scan direction pose difficulty for mesh manipulation, in particular for off-line, preprocessed applications. For example, mesh simplification algorithms are unable to predict user scan direction, thus conservative thresholds should be used for reliability while sacrificing performance. This problem may be alleviated by the fact that the actual threshold differences were not so large in Exp. 4, but an expanded investigation is necessary to obtain more comprehensive data.

Comparisons to previous studies

In this section, we compare the difference thresholds most related to the present study among those previously published. These thresholds are compiled in Table 3 with a summary of experimental methods.

The most relevant work, as cited earlier, is one which used the same haptic device (PHANToM) to measure the 79.4 % correct difference thresholds of plane orientation (Giachritsis et al. 2009). These thresholds ranged from 8.1 to 13.8° and were similar to those of the present study (8.33−12.74°). This is despite the differences in surface position (middle vs. right) and in surface orientation (90°  vs.  0°), so also in scan direction (front–back vs. left–right). In the literature, there exist evidence for the dependence of surface orientation perception on the position and orientation of a reference surface, in terms of orientation reproduction (Kappers and Koenderink 1999) and absolute bias (Henriques and Soechting 2003). However, the reference pose was shown insignificant for orientation discrimination in Henriques and Soechting (2003). This sensitivity dependency on the hand position and scan direction is of considerably consequence to mesh processing and thus deserves further exploration.

In Henriques and Soechting (2003), a two-DOF robotic manipulator rendered virtual planes at a number of positions and orientations, and the 75 % difference thresholds of orientation were reported. Even with the 4.4 % percentile gap, Footnote 2 the about 4.9° thresholds of Henriques and Soechting (2003) were generally smaller than those of our study and Giachritsis et al. (2009). One noteworthy difference is that considerably higher stiffness (2 N/mm) and damping (5 Ns/mm) were used for virtual surface rendering in Henriques and Soechting (2003) than ours (0.2–0.65 N/mm and 0 damping) and those of Giachritsis et al. (2009) (0.9 N/mm and 0 damping). Such rigid virtual surfaces allow much smaller penetration of a tool and diminish initial probe oscillations and curvy trajectories (e.g., Fig. 8), which are common for PHANToM-like low-stiffness impedance devices. Thus, they may provide better-defined stimuli for proprioceptive spatial integration, implying that considerably stiffer virtual surfaces, e.g., those renderable using high-stiffness, desktop, parallel-linkage commercial devices, may lead to significantly improved orientation discrimination. Therefore, the current finding of slope discrimination being independent of virtual surface stiffness might be confined to low-stiffness surfaces.

Lastly, the rightmost column in Table 3 presents 79.4 %-correct angle discrimination thresholds measured from two adjoined planes (Voisin et al. 2002b). Two thresholds are shown, one explored by the (intact) index finger and the other by the same finger deprived of cutaneous feedback using anesthesia. Unlike bare finger pad exploration, point-contact haptic devices such as PHANToM can produce only temporal tactile stimuli, but not spatial tactile stimuli. Thus, angle difference thresholds for virtual surfaces are expected to be between the two cases (4.9 and 8.8°), which are slightly smaller than the slope discrimination thresholds. It might be the case that angle discrimination between two planes can be more sensitive than orientation discrimination of each plane and a more limiting factor for 3D mesh processing. Further investigation using haptic virtual surfaces seems necessary.

Implications to force constancy

The analysis of dynamic stimuli along with the difference thresholds presented in Sect. 4 also impart some new insights regarding the theory of force constancy. Previously, it was shown that the user exerts a constant contact force while scanning a virtual surface parallel to the body frontal plane (Choi et al. 2005). This experimental setup was identical to those of Exps. 1–3 of the present study. Some results of this study, e.g., the penetration depth plots shown in Fig. 8 and the force variance analysis reported in Sect. 4.1, also corroborate the force constancy theory. The force constancy behavior was also confirmed by Chib et al. (2006) for a tool transfer task exposed to force fields of various stiffness. Participants were observed to maintain an invariant force level soon after an initial adaptation phase.

The data analysis, especially in Exp. 4, also discovered an exploratory behavior that disobeys the force constancy theory. In Fig. 10, the PHANToM response force showed continuous increase during inward plane scans. This tendency was more apparent for scans toward the body (IL). This result signifies the need to refine the force constancy theory, taking into account other factors. One plausible candidate is the springlike mechanical property of the human arm.

For elaboration, let F a be the normal force exerted by the arm and hand muscles to the tool and F r be the restoring force that acts to the opposite direction of the arm movement caused by the arm elasticity, as shown in Fig. 11. F h is the total normal force applied by the hand to a virtual surface. The haptic device renders forces of the same magnitude as F h but to the opposite direction. For probe movements incoming to the body (right two cases in Fig. 11), F a and F r have the same direction, thus F h  = F a  + F r . Even though F a may remain invariant due to force constancy, F r can increase as the hand moves closer to the body [see the stiffness ellipsoids in Mussa-Ivaldi et al. (1985, p. 2740)], making F h increase over time as shown by the dotted lines in Fig. 10. For outgoing probe movements, F a and F r are in the opposite directions, thus F h  = F a  − F r . Based the same logic, one would expect F h to decrease over time. Traces for outward scans in Fig. 10 indeed demonstrated evidence of this behavior, especially for OR, but with a weaker degree than incoming movements. A dedicated study seems necessary to be fully explain haptic exploratory behaviors for surfaces of various orientations and scan directions.

Conclusions

Motivated by the emerging needs for sensation-preserving geometric data processing in computer haptics, this paper has investigated the haptic discriminability between the body frontal plane and a sloped plane rendered via a force–feedback interface, taking into account the effects of five factors: surface stiffness, scan velocity, scan length, and normal/tangent movement direction of the hand. Primary findings are: (1) the slope discrimination thresholds ranged from 8.33° to 12.74°; (2) surface stiffness and lateral scan velocity were shown irrelevant to the slope discriminability for the tested ranges; (3) scans toward the body (in the forward-backward direction) and from left-to-right scans improved the sensitivity; and (4) the terminal position difference along the normal direction seems to be a salient somatosensory cue for slope perception. The implications of these experimental results to recent haptics applications involving 3D geometry manipulation are also discussed, along with several open questions which we plan to study in the future.

    Let θ i be the plane slope at the i th trial. Then for \(\Updelta \theta\) in dB,

    $$ \theta_{i+1} = 10^{\frac{\Updelta \theta}{20}} \; \theta_i. $$
    (9)
  2. 2.

    For more strict comparison, our thresholds can be converted to 75 % thresholds using a psychometric function estimation method from adaptive staircase data [e.g., Leek et al. (1992); Kontsevich and Tyler (1999)]. However, according to Leek et al. (1992), the numbers of trials of our experiments (about 50–100) is so small that excessive bias would result in the estimated function slope. Hence, we just present the original thresholds.
